docs.lead_paragraph: Herman Badillo, a Republican mayoral candidate, said yesterday that he would govern New York almost exactly the way Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had to protect the ''dramatic improvements that have taken place'' in the last eight years. Mr. Badillo said there would be only stylistic differences between a Badillo and a Giuliani administration. He said he would keep at least two of Mr. Giuliani's commissioners, Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik and Nicholas Scoppetta, the commissioner of the Administration for Children's Services.

headline.main: Badillo Says He'll Safeguard Progress of the Giuliani Era

docs.abstract: Interview with Herman Badillo, part of series of interviews with New York City mayoral candidates; Badillo says he would emulate Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani to protect 'dramatic improvements' of his tenure; photo (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: You would think no one had ever enacted a state budget before. Over the last several years, Gov. George E. Pataki of New York and legislative leaders have repeatedly put new obstacles in the path to budget deals, found new reasons to jettison the way things were done before, and set records for lateness. The result is an annual, fruitless search for a new approach they all can live with.

headline.main: For Albany, the One Constant Is a Late Budget

docs.abstract: Analysis of New York's quest for budget process legislative leaders and governor can live with; notes state is on 17-year streak of late budgets, national record by far, with budget process out of control since mid-1990's (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Here are excerpts from an interview with Herman Badillo, a Republican who is making his fourth attempt to become mayor of New York City. The interview was conducted by reporters and editors from The New York Times, and is the second in a planned series of interviews with each of the major candidates. Q. What, in your view, are the stakes in this election? What is this election about?

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration has refused to approve a New York proposal to provide subsidized contraceptive services to hundreds of thousands of low-income New Yorkers, placing Gov. George E. Pataki in a political quandary. New York officials had been urging the federal government to approve the state's plan to offer family planning services to the needy using both state and federal Medicaid money.

headline.main: Bush Opposes Plan by Albany To Subsidize Birth Control

docs.abstract: Bush administration opposes New York proposal to use both state and federal Medicaid money to subsidize contraceptive services for some 400,000 low-income residents who earn too much to qualify for Medicaid and do not get health benefits from employers; holds proposal is too narrow, seeking to expand Medicaid coverage for single type of service; stand places Gov George E Pataki, who approved plan, in political quandary; Democratic lawmakers, women's groups and family planning advocates score stand; see effort to please Bush's conservative supporters; notes similar programs were approved in at least nine other states during Clinton administration (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional champions of patients' rights sent a blistering response today to President Bush's latest proposal on the issue, but invited the president to enter high-stakes negotiations to achieve a legislative compromise. The Congressional response was sent to the White House by Representative Charlie Norwood, the Georgia Republican who is a leader of efforts to pass a patients' bill of rights. The document was prepared by Mr. Norwood and the principal supporters of his bill, including senior lawmakers from both parties and both houses of Congress.

headline.main: Lawmakers Rebuff Bush on Patients' Rights

docs.abstract: Bipartisan group of Congressional champions of patients' rights, led by Rep Charlie Norwood, sends blistering response to Pres Bush's latest proposal on issue but invites Bush to enter negotiations to forge compromise; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president who wants to be mayor, is waging a campaign to revive what he says is a tradition of activist government abandoned by Rudolph W. Giuliani and bolster ''the other New York'' left out of the city's economic boom. Mr. Ferrer, a Democrat, sketched the broad outlines of his mayoral vision yesterday, including an array of expensive government programs the size and cost of which recall another era in the city's politics. Mr. Ferrer said that he hoped to pay for most of his new programs with taxes already collected and requests for more state aid, and by weeding out fraud and abuse. He said he did not think raising taxes would be necessary to cover expansion of programs and services, but favored reinstating an income tax surcharge that was recently rolled back by Mr. Giuliani and the City Council.

headline.main: Ferrer Envisions a New Era Of Activism by Government

docs.abstract: First of six articles on New York City mayoral candidates discusses Fernando Ferrer's campaign to revive activist government and help those left out of economic boom; Democratic boro president, interviewed by The New York Times, outlines expensive government programs that recall another era in city politics; says he would pay for them with taxes already collected, with more state aid, by weeding out fraud and abuse and by reinstating income tax surcharge; Ferrer indicates he would be more likely to discipline police officers and would ban racial profiling; proposes to raise teacher pay thirty percent and build 150,000 housing units; photo campaigning with Geraldine Ferraro (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: No one has gone to the mat more for President Bush than Representative J. Dennis Hastert, the burly, low-key House speaker who long labored as a high school wrestling coach. Often the struggle has not been pretty. Some of Mr. Hastert's own Republican teammates in the House are bruised and staggering.
docs.abstract: News analysis of scramble by Pres Bush and Republican leaders to forge deal on patients' bill of rights in face of broad public support for broad right to sue insurance companies, as contained in bipartisan bill backed by Democrats; Speaker Dennis Hastert, who has passed several critical bills and spared Pres Bush from embarrassing defeat, confers with Bush at Capitol and talks with undecided Republicans; photo; Senate has already passed Democratic version, and Republicans fear they will suffer at polls if Bush makes good on veto threat (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush offered new concessions to Congress today on legislation to define patients' rights, but Democrats said the proposals did not go far enough to satisfy their concerns. Mr. Bush met at the White House with Representative Charlie Norwood, the Republican leader of a six-year Congressional effort to set strict federal standards for health insurance. Later, at the Capitol, Mr. Bush met with Speaker J. Dennis Hastert to discuss the issue.

headline.main: Bush Gives on Patients Bill, But Democrats Want More

docs.lead_paragraph: Here are excerpts of an interview with Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president and a Democratic candidate for mayor, conducted by several editors and reporters of The New York Times. The Times plans to hold similar sessions with each of the other major candidates. Q. You've defined your constituency as something you've called ''the other New York.'' I wonder if you would talk more about what the other New York is: Who is ''the other New York''? And how is it defined? Is it defined geographically? By ethnic group? By income? By attitude?

headline.main: Ferrer Defines the 'Other New York,' and He Discusses His Plans to Help It
